--- title: "A Summary of My Research in Stats and Medicine" author: "Ray Pomponio" date: "2023-12-30" categories: [news] --- As we're nearing the end of the calendar year, I thought it a good opportunity to present my research in a blog post that identifies three different themes across the statistical and biomedical applications that I've worked on. Those themes are: **computational**, **clinical**, and **missing data methods**. I'll cover each theme in more detail below. I've been fortunate to co-author a number of published papers over the past five years, and I'll include links to relevant articles where they fit within the above themes. ### Theme 1: Research in Computational Neuroimaging ![Figure from Pomponio et al. (2020): Age trends for selected brain volumes using a statistically harmonized dataset with 18 studies spanning the age range 3â€“96.](trends.jpeg) In 2018, I began working at [CBICA](https://www.med.upenn.edu/cbica/), a computational neuroimaging lab at the University of Pennsylvania, led by Dr. Christos Davatzikos. At CBICA, I developed an early expertise in statistical image analysis, particularly in the challenges of normalizing imaging-derived features over multiple scanners and geographic sites. In the imaging literature, this is referred to as [harmonization](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1053811922006851#:~:text=Harmonization%20is%20typically%20performed%20to,downstream%20application%20performance%20during%20harmonization.), and there are a growing number of techniques available to implement harmonization techniques. My major contribution was to develop a tool that adapted the popular ComBat[^1] algorithm to lifespan datasets encompassing vast age ranges, with potentially complex age trends in brain volumetry. Today, that tool is available on [GitHub](https://github.com/rpomponio/neuroHarmonize) as a python package, and it is used by neuroimaging researchers to handle common harmonization tasks like removing site effects. In addition to my work on harmonization, I assisted with image analysis in several other projects that resulted in peer-reviewed publications by the following first authors: * [Dr. Ilya M. Nasrallah](https://www.med.upenn.edu/apps/faculty/index.php/g20000440/p9094), Associate Professor of Radiology at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania * [Dr. Mohamad Habes](https://www.nallab.org/pi), Assistant Professor, Departments of Radiology and Epidemiology at the University of Texas Health Science Center San Antonio * Dr. Ganesh Chand, Assistant Professor at Washington University in St. Louis * Vishnu M. Bashyam, PhD student at the University of Pennsylvania ```{html}
